title-group.article-title: Five undescribed steroids from Talaromyces stipitatus and their cytotoxic activities against hepatoma cell lines

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Five undescribed steroids from Talaromyces stipitatus and their cytotoxic activities against hepatoma cell lines
Mi Zhang a, 1 , Yanfang Deng a, 1 , Fei Liu a , Meijia Zheng a , Yu Liang a , Weiguang Sun a , Qin Li a ,
Xiao-Nian Li b , Changxing Qi a , Junjun Liu a , Chunmei Chen a, ** , Hucheng Zhu a, *** ,
Yonghui Zhang a, *
a Hubei Key Laboratory of Natural Medicinal Chemistry and Resource Evaluation, Tongji Medical College, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan ,
430030, People’ s Republic of China
b State Key Laboratory of Phytochemistry and Plant Resources in West China , Kunming Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Kunming, 650204, People’ s
Republic of China
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Steroids
Cytotoxicity
A B S T R A C T

Five undescribed sterol derivatives, (22 E ,24 R )-7 α -methoxy-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22-diene-3 β ,15 β -diol, (22 E ,24 R )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22-diene-3 β ,7 β ,15 α -triol, (22 E ,24 R )-3 β ,5 α -dihydroxy-14 β ,15 β -epoxyergosta-7,22-diene-6-one, (22 E ,24 R )-6 α -methoxy-7 α ,15 β -dihydroxyergosta-4,8(14),22-triene-3-one, and (25 S )- ergosta-7,24(28)-diene-3 β ,4 α ,6 α ,26 - tetraol were isolated from the extract of Talaromyces stipitatus , along with eight known congeners. This is the first example of a class of ergosterols isolated from T. stipitatus . Their structures with absolute configurations were elucidated based on NMR spectroscopic data, ECD calculations, and X-ray crystallographic analyses. All these compounds were tested for their effects on three hepatoma cell lines including Hep3B, HepG2, and Huh-7. Moreover, (22 E ,24 R )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22-diene-3 β ,7 β ,15 α -triol and (22 E ,24 R )-9 α ,15 α -dihydroxyergosta-4,6,8(14),22-tetraen-3-one were further evaluated for their impacts on cell cycle progression and apoptosis due to their pronounced cytotoxicity, to uncover their underlying mechanisms. Our results suggested that their antiproliferative activities were mainly mediated by inducing cell apoptosis.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Steroids are a critical source of natural products, which not only act as a pivotal part of membranes to maintain structures, but are also the office of precursors for the synthesis of important substances such as steroid hormones ( ; ; ; ). Ergosterols are a subclass of steroids, that possess a typical tetracyclic skeleton with an alkyl chain and hydroxyl groups. Apart from classical ergosterols with the mentioned carbon skeleton, rearranged ergosterols have also reported, and some of them have been synthesized, such as dankasterones A and B, resulting from 13 (14 → 8) abeo -frameworks as intermediaries to form unprecedented structures ( ; ). A large number of natural ergosterols have exhibited significant anti-inflammatory (Xiang et al., 2018), anti-tumor ( ), anti-bacterial ( ), and neurotrophic activities ( ).

Talaromyces stipitatus C.R. Benj. ( Trichocomaceae ) is a potential but underexplored species, closely related to Penicillium , which is known to produce polyketides and terpenoids as principal products ( ; Zang et al., 2016a). An incredible examplification of remarkable structural complexity and biological diversity in polyketides from T. stipitatus is the duclauxin derivatives, which are a series of oxaphenalenone dimers that comprise the 6/6/6/5/6/6/6 ring system ( ; ; ; Zang et al., 2016b). In our previous report, four fusicoccane diterpenoids with an unparalleled 5/8/6 carbon skeleton were obtained (Zhang et al., 2020), which stimulated us to further explore diverse bioactive compounds from T. stipitatus .
* Corresponding author.
** Corresponding author.
*** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: chenchunmei@hust.edu.cn (C. Chen), zhuhucheng@hust.edu.cn (H. Zhu), zhangyh@mails.tjmu.edu.cn (Y. Zhang).
1 These authors contributed equally to this work.

As part of our ongoing investigation, five undescribed ergosterol derivatives ( 1–2 and 4–6 ) along with eight known congeners were identified. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a class of ergosterols isolated from T. stipitatus . All of these compounds were evaluated for their antiproliferative activities against Hep3B, HepG2, and Huh-7 hepatoma cell lines. Compounds 4 and 8 showed a remarkable cytotoxicity, cell cycle progression and apoptosis induced by the two compounds and therefore were detected in order to explain the mechanisms of their function. Meanwhile, the selectivity of both compounds on hepatoma suggested their potential as drug candidates against hepatoma.

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p: Compound 1 was obtained as a white powder. Its molecular formula was established as C 29 H 46 O 4 based on the HRESIMS ion peak at m/z 481.3262 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 29 H 46 O 4 Na, 481.3294), requiring a hydrogen deficiency index of seven. The 1 H NMR spectrum showed signals for two olefinic protons [ δ H 5.26 (1H, dd, J = 15.2, 7.3 Hz, H-22) and 5.24 (1H, dd, J = 15.2, 8.1 Hz, H-23)], six methyls [ δ H 1.06 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 1.03 (3H, d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -21), 0.96 (3H, d, J = 7.5 Hz, H 3 -28), 0.95 (3H, s, H 3 -19), 0.87 (3H, d, J = 7.5 Hz, H 3 -26), and 0.86 (3H, d, J = 7.3 Hz, H 3 -27)], and one methoxy group [ δ H 3.47 (3H, s, H-29)]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 1 displayed 29 carbons, corresponding to four olefinic carbons, three quaternary carbons (one oxygenated), nine methine carbons (four oxygenated), six methylenes, and seven methyl groups (including a methoxy). These typical signals suggested 1 to be an ergostane-type steroid derivative.

The 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC experiments ( Fig. 2 ) revealed that compound 1 possesses a structure similar to (22 E )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8 (14),22-diene-3 β ,7 α ,15 α -triol ( 3 ). The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 1 displayed an additional methoxy ( δ C 55.6, Me-29) as compared with 3 , which along with the HMBC spectrum correlation from Me-29 to C-7 ( δ C 72.4) confirmed the existence of a methoxy at C-7. The relative configuration of 1 was determined based on its NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 3 ) and key coupling constants. Generally, Me-18 of sterols is β -oriented and the NOESY signal of Me-18/H-11a revealed that they were cofacial and should adopt a dipseudoaxial relationship. Moreover, the NOESY correlations of Me-19/H-11a and Me-19/H-7 indicated the β -orientation of Me-19 and H-7, which also suggested the α -orientation of the epoxy ring at C-5 and C-6. In addition, the interactions of Me-19/H-1a and H-3/H- 1b along with the coupling constant of H-3 (tt, J = 11.1, 5.6 Hz) revealed the β -orientation of C-3-OH. The NOESY correlation of C-7-OCH 3 /H-15 disclosed the β -orientation of C-15-OH. The trans stereochemistry of the double bond was then deduced from the coupling constant between H-22 and H-23 ( J = 15.2 Hz). The relative configurations of the remaining chiral centers, including C-21 and C-28, were determined to be identical to these of 3 by comparison of their 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( ). Finally, the structure of 1 with an absolute configuration was determined via X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 5 ). Thus, compound 1 was determined to be (22 E ,24 R )-7 α -methoxy-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8 (14),22-diene-3 β ,15 β -diol.

Compound 2 was isolated as a white powder, which shared the same molecular formula of C 28 H 44 O 4 as that of 3 based on the HRESIMS data. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 2 ( Tables 1 and 2 ) closely resembled those of 3 , except for the obviously shifted signals of C-5 (1.9 ppm), C-6 (+ 1.0 ppm), C-7 (1.5 ppm), C-8 (+ 2.6 ppm), and C-14 (2.6 ppm). After detailed analyses of the 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC spectra, 2 and 3 were a pair of stereoisomers possessing the same planar structure. The NOESY interaction of Me-19/C-7-OH ( Fig. 3 ), along with the abovementioned changes in the 13 C NMR data, suggested that 2 is the C-7 epimer of 3 . The structure and absolute configuration of compound 2 was further determined by X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 5 ). Therefore, compound 2 was elucidated as (22 E ,24 R )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22- diene-3 β ,7 β ,15 α -triol.

Compound 4 was obtained as a white powder. Its molecular formula, C 28 H 42 O 4 , was determined using the HRESIMS spectrum with a pseudomolecular ion peak at m/z 465.2990 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 28 H 42 O 4 Na, 465.2981), suggesting eight degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum indicated the presence of hydroxy ( 3386 cm 1 ) and conjugated carbonyl ( 1676 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H NMR spectrum indicated signals for three olefinic protons [ δ H 5.83 (1H, d, J = 2.8 Hz, H-7), 5.38 (1H, dd, J = 15.3, 8.1 Hz, H-22), and 5.20 (1H, dd, J = 15.3, 8.1 Hz, H-23)], six methyls [ δ H 1.01 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 0.98 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -28), 0.95 (3H, d, J = 6.2 Hz, H 3 -21), 0.94 (3H, s, H 3 -19), 0.88 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz,H 3 -27), and 0.85 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -26)], and two oxygenated methine groups [ δ H 3.94 (1H, tt, J = 11.6, 4.6 Hz, H-3) and 3.22 (1H, m, H-15)]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 4 revealed 28 carbons, including one conjugated carbonyl, four olefinic carbons, four quaternary carbons, seven methines (two oxygenated), six methylenes, and six methyl groups. These data of compound 4 resembled those of gymnastrone B ( ), except for the presence of additional hydroxy groups at C-3 and C-5 and the disappearance of the carbonyl at C-3. Further analyses of the 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlations of 4 ( Fig. 2 ) elucidated the planar structure of 4 . The NOESY cross-peak between Me-19 and H-4b revealed that they were cofacial (in a dipseudoaxial relationship), which indirectly proved the α -orientation of C-5-OH. The obvious NOESY correlations of H-3/H-1a and H-1b/Me-19, and the coupling constants of H-3 (tt, J = 11.1, 4.6 Hz) revealed the β -orientation of C-3-OH. The orientation of the epoxy at C-14 and C-15 was assigned as β by a comparison of the NMR data of 4 with that of gymnastrrone B. Thus, the relative configuration of 4 was established. The absolute configuration of 4 was confirmed via X-ray diffraction analysis as shown ( Fig. 5 ). Therefore, 4 was elucidated as (22 E ,24 R )-3 β , 5 α -dihydroxy-14 β ,15 β -epoxyergosta-7,22-diene-6-one.

Compound 5 was isolated as a colorless oil, and its molecular formula was deduced to be C 29 H 44 O 4 based on the HRESIMS ion peak at m/z 479.3138 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 29 H 44 O 4 Na, 479.3137). The 1 H NMR spectrum indicated signals for three olefinic protons [ δ H 6.15 (1H, d, J = 1.9 Hz, H-4), 5.20 (1H, m, H-22), and 5.20 (1H, m, H-23)], six methyls [ δ H 1.11 (3H, s, H 3 -19), 1.04 (3H, d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -21), 0.91 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -28), 0.87 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 0.82 (3H, d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -27), and 0.80 (3H, d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -26)], one methoxy group [ δ H 3.48 (1H, s, H-29)], and three oxygenated methine groups [ δ H 4.90 (1H, d, J = 4.1 Hz, H-7), 4.83 (1H, d, J = 4.8 Hz, H-15), and 3.89 (1H, dd, J = 4.1,1.9 Hz, H- 6),]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 5 displayed 29 carbons, established as one conjugated carbonyl, six olefinic carbons, two quaternary carbons, eight methines (three oxygenated), five methylenes, and seven methyl groups. The 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC data revealed that compound 5 possessed a similar structure as 10 did ( ), except for the presence of an additional methoxy at C-6 and hydroxyl at C-7. In the HMBC spectrum, correlations from H-4 to C-6 ( δ C 79.0) and from H-7 to C-9 ( δ C 42.8) and C-14 ( δ C 157.1), along with the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-6 ( δ H 3.89)/H-7 ( δ H 4.90), confirmed the existence of the methoxy at C-6 and hydroxyl at C-7. The relative configuration of 5 was determined by its NOESY spectrum and H–H coupling constants. Based on the NOESY correlations of Me-19/H-6, Me-19/H-11, and H-11/Me-18, Me-18, Me-19, and H-6 were assigned to be β -oriented and in the dipseudoaxial relationship. Therefore, the coupling constant of H-6 and H-7 ( J 6,7 = 3.8 Hz) indicated the α -orientation of C-7-OH. In addition, the obvious NOESY correlation of H-20/Me-18 indicated the α -orientation of H-17, and according to the NOESY correlation of H-17/H-15, H-15 and H-17 were in the same orientation. Thus, the relative configuration of 5 was established. Since the theoretical ECD curve of 6 R ,7 S ,9 S , 10 R ,13 R ,15 R ,17 R ,20 R ,24 R -5 matched well with the experimental ECD curve of 5 ( Fig. 4 ), the absolute configuration of 5 was determined as shown. Therefore, 5 was elucidated as (22 E , 24 R )-6 α -methoxy-7 α ,15 β -dihydroxyergosta-4,8(14),22-triene-3-one.

Compound 6 was isolated as colorless needles, and its molecular formula was determined to be C 28 H 46 O 4 based on its HRESIMS ion peak at m/z 469.3277 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 28 H 46 O 4 Na, 469.3294), suggesting six degrees of unsaturation. The 1 H NMR spectrum showed signals for four olefinic protons [ δ H 5.12 (1H, d, J = 2.1 Hz, H-7), 4.77 (1H, brs, H 2 -28), and 4.75 (1H, brs, H-28)], four methyls [ δ H 1.06 (3H, d, J = 7.0 Hz, H 3 -27), 0.99 (3H, d, J = 6.5 Hz, H 3 -21), 0.89 (3H, s, H 3 -19), and 0.59 (3H, s H 3 -18)], one oxygenated methylene group [ δ H 3.58 (1H, dd, J = 10.7, 5.9 Hz, H 2 -26), δ H 3.35 (1H, m, H 2 -26)], and three oxygenated methines [ δ H 4.28 (1H, dd, J = 9.3, 2.1 Hz,H-6), 3.72 (1H, dd, J = 10.2, 8.9 Hz, H-4) and 3.35 (1H, m, H-3)]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 6 revealed 28 carbons, corresponding to four olefinic carbons, two quaternary carbons, nine methine carbons (three oxygenated), nine methylene (one oxygenated), and four methyl groups. Careful analyses of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra revealed that compound 6 is similar to (25 S )-24-methyl-5 α -cholest-24( 241 )-ene- 3 β ,4 β ,6 α ,15 β, 26 - pentol (certonardosterol B) ( ) except for the absence of a hydroxy at C-15 and the presence of a double bond between C-7 and C-8 ( Fig. 1 ). The relative configuration of the nucleus is consistent with certonardosterol B and the absolute configuration was confirmed via X-ray diffraction analysis. Therefore, 6 was established as (25 S )-ergosta-7,24(28)-diene-3 β ,4 α ,6 α ,26 - tetraol.
a Recorded in Methanol- d .
4 b Recorded in DMSO d .
‑ 6 c Recorded in CDCl.
a Recorded in Methanol- d .
4 b Recorded in DMSO d .
‑ 6 c Recorded in CDCl. “o” means overlapped.

Compounds 3 and 7–13 were identified as (22 E )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22-diene-3 β ,7 α ,15 α -triol ( 3 ) ( ), (22 E , 24 R )-ergosta-3 β ,5 α -dihydroxy-7,22-dien-6-one ( 7 ) ( ), (22 E ,24 R )-9 α ,15 α -dihydroxyergosta-4,6,8(14),22-tetraen-3-one ( 8 ) ( ), 15 R , 20 R, 24 R , Δ 4,6,8(14),22 -tetraene-3-one-ergosterol ( 9 ) ( ), 15 S , 20 R , 24 R , Δ 4,6,8(14),22 -tetraene-3-one-ergosterol ( 10 ) ( ), (22 E ,24 R )-ergosta-4,6,8(14), 22-tetraen-3,15-dione ( 11 ) ( ), (22 E ,24 R )-ergosta-5 β , 6 β -epoxy-3 β ,7 α ,9 α -trihydroxy-8(14),22-dien-15-one ( 12 ) ( ), and (22 E ,24 R )-ergosta-7,22-dien-3,5,6-triol ( 13 ) ( ) by the comparison of their NMR data with those reported in the literature.

Compounds 1–13 were tested for their effects on hepatoma cell lines including Hep3B, HepG2, and Huh-7. As a result, compounds 4 , 8 , 9 , 10 , and 11 demonstrated potent inhibition against the tested hepatoma cell lines (Fig. S56). Subsequently, we determined the IC 50 values of these compounds in the three cell lines. As observed in Table 3 , compounds 4 and 8 showed remarkable cytotoxic effects against the Hep3B and HepG2 cell lines with IC 50 values ranging from 4.75 to 8.85 μ M and 5.26–6.29 μ M, respectively. For the Huh-7 cells, there was a slight increase in the IC 50 values of both compounds, 13.78 and 16.23 μ M respectively. Compounds 9 , 10 , and 11 were generally less potently cytotoxic against the cell lines used compared to compounds 4 and 8 .
a Results are expressed as the mean standard error.
± b Positive control.
c N.T.-not determined.

Compounds 4 and 8 demonstrated pronounced cytotoxicity in the hepatoma cell lines, therefore, we further explored to gain insight into the mechanism of their actions. To examine whether compounds 4 and 8 have effects on cell cycle progression, we detected the DNA content using flow cytometry. As shown in Fig. 6 , compound 8 increased the proportion of S phase cells to 47.06 ± 2.06%, compared with 33.08 ± 1.80% of the corresponding controls, at 5 μ M for 24 h on Hep3B cells (p < 0.001), resulting in a significant decrease in the G2 phase (p < 0.01). Our results suggested that the antiproliferative effect of compound 8 was associated with its ability to induce S phase cell cycle arrest. Thus, no significant changes were observed in cells treated with compound 4 .

Since compound 4 exerted a slight impact on cell cycle progression, we presumed that other factors might also participate in its inhibitory effect against the Hep3B cells. In view of this, a flow cytometric analysis was performed to determine the cell apoptosis death induced by compounds 4 and 8 . As observed in Fig. 7 , the proportion of apoptotic cells induced by compound 8 increased from 12.5 ± 0.5% at 24 h to 41.2 ± 1.1% at 48 h and 5 μ M. The latter value was ten times higher than that of the control group (3.9 ± 1.0%, p < 0.0001) considering early and late apoptosis. On the other hand, cells treated with compound 4 at 5 μ M for 48h displayed 41.1 ± 1.3% apoptosis, a value much higher than that of the control (p < 0.0001). Both treatment groups showed no significant difference (p > 0.05) from the positive control sorafenib ( ) (44.6 ± 0.9%) at 48 h ( Fig. 7 ).

Given that cells undergoing apoptosis show nuclear fragmentation and chromatin condensation ( ), we examined the morphological changes in Hep3B cells after treatment with 5 μ M compounds 4 and 8 for 48 h. In keeping with sorafenib, cells treated with compounds 4 or 8 showed typical apoptotic features such as DNA fragmentation, condensed chromatin and apoptotic bodies compared with the solvent control (0.1% DMSO), as depicted in Fig. 8 . These results provided convincing evidence that compounds 4 and 8 induced apoptosis and cell death.

To determine the toxic effects of compounds 4 and 8 against normal cells and thus show their selectivity for hepatoma cells, their IC 50 values against the nontumorous human liver cell line LO2 were also evaluated. Compounds 4 and 8 were 49.3 and 57.1 μ M respectively, which were significantly higher (p < 0.001 and p < 0.001) than those on target hepatoma cell lines. These data indicate that compounds 4 and 8 can selectively trigger cell death in hepatoma cells, suggesting their potential for further consideration as lead compounds.

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p: Talaromyces stipitatus is a universal species of the genus Talaromyces , and previous investigations have indicted the potential of the compounds in terms of their structural diversity and complexity. In our current study, a series of ergosterols were discovered, including five new ergosterols along with eight known compounds. Notably, compounds 4 and 8 displayed a remarkable cytotoxicity against the hepatoma cell lines. The results of the cell cycle progression and apoptosis suggested that their effects were mainly mediated by inducing apoptosis. Our findings have enriched the chemical diversity and bioactivity of sterols.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: Optical rotations, ECD, UV, IR spectra and high-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESIMS) were conducted on the instruments we utilized in a previous report. (Zhang et al., 2020). Crystallographic experiments were performed on a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Cu K α radiation ( λ = 1.54178 Å). Semipreparative high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) utilized an Agilent 1260 equipped with a UV detector, using a Welch Ultimate XB-C 18 column (5 μ m, 10 × 250 mm ). Silica gel (Qingdao Marine Chemical Inc., China ), Sephadex LH-20 (GE Healthcare Bio-Sciences AB, Sweden ), and ODS (50 μ m,Merck, Germany ) were utilized in the column chromatography. Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was performed using silica gel 60 F 254 (Yantai Chemical Industry Research Institute).

sec.title: 4.2. Fungal material
sec.p: The fungus Talaromyces stipitatus was isolated from the soil of Beijing , China . An NCBI BLAST analysis of its partial sequence
(BNCC226199) showed that it is 100% identical to T stipitatus strain CBS 236.60 (MH857968.1) and T stipitatus strain T1D1 (MN518410.1).

sec.title: 4.3. Fermentation and isolation
sec.p: The fermentation and extraction of the fungal Talaromyces stipitatus C.R. Benj. ( Trichocomaceae ) were identical to the procedures described previously (Zhang et al., 2020). Briefly fungi were cultivated on a solid-substrate medium ( 35 kg ) for 32 days at 25 ◦ C. Exhaustive extraction with EtOAc resulted in a crude fraction (250.0 g) which was partitioned by silica gel CC with a gradient elution petroleum ether/- EtOAc (10:1 to EtOAc neat, v/v) to obtain six subfractions (Fr.1–6). Since the steroids were mainly enriched in Fr.2 ( 10.3 g ) and Fr.3 (28.0 g), Fr.2 was further chromatographed on Sephadex LH-20 (MeOH), ODS (50%–100%, v/v) and semipreparative HPLC to afford compounds 4 ( 3.2 mg ), 7 (5.0 mg), 9 ( 3.5 mg ), 10 (3.0 mg), and 13 ( 7.5 mg ). Fr.3 was purified by RP-C18 gel with MeOH/H 2 O (60%–100%, v/v) to give seven fractions (Fr.3A Fr.3G) grounded on the TLC analysis. The Fr.3E was successively separated using silica gel CC with ether/EtOAc (15:1 to 1:1, v/v) and Sephadex LH-20, and then purified by semipreparative HPLC to yield compounds 1 ( 4.1 mg ), 2 ( 5.3 mg ), 3 (7.0 mg), 8 ( 3.3 mg ), and 11 ( 9.5 mg ). Similarly, compounds 5 ( 2.2 mg ), 6 ( 3.9 mg ), and 12 ( 6.1 mg ) were isolated from Fr. 3F.

sec.title: 4.3.1. Compound 1
sec.p: White powder; [ α ] D –175.0 ( c 0.1, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 212 (16.7); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 208 (4.09) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3420, 3059, 2957, 2934, 1634, 1462, 1382, 1058, 1036, 708, 651 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (CD 3 OD, 400 MHz) data, see Table 1 ; 13 C NMR (CD 3 OD, 100 MHz) data, see Table 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 481.3262 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 29 H 46 O 4 Na, 481.3294).

sec.title: 4.3.2. Compound 2
sec.p: White powder; [ α ] D 25 –14 ( c 0.1, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 218 (6.35) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 211 (4.34) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3374,

2955, 2868, 1738, 1723, 1452, 1383, 1124, 702 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 400 MHz) data, see Table 1 ; 13 C NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 100 MHz) data, see Table 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 467.3128 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 28 H 44 O 4 Na, 467.3137).

sec.title: 4.3.3. Compound 4
sec.p: White powder; [ α ] D 25 –16 ( c 0.1, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 209 (+ 5.36), 254 (15.2) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 255 (4.02) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3444, 3386, 2959, 2874, 1712, 1676, 1461, 1384, 1278, 1163, 772 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (CD 3 OD, 400 MHz) data, see Table 1 ; 13 C NMR (CD 3 OD, 100 MHz) data, see Table 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 465.2990 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 28 H 42 O 4 Na, 465.2981).

sec.title: 4.3.4. Compound 5
sec.p: Colorless oil; [ α ] D 25 + 16 ( c 0.1, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 216 (2.6), 254 (+ 3.5) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 238 (3.45) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3442, 3385, 2958, 2871, 1711, 1664, 1462, 1383, 1221, 1009, 778 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) data, see Table 1 ; 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz) data, see Table 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 479.3138 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 29 H 44 O 4 Na, 479.3137).

sec.title: 4.3.5. Compound 6
sec.p: Colorless needles; [ α ] D 25 + 31 ( c 0.1, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δ ε ) 207 (9.1) nm; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 202 (3.83) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3440, 2963, 2931, 2874, 1690, 1618, 1458, 1384, 1290, 1180, 1094, 884 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR (CD 3 OD, 400 MHz) data, see Table 1 ; 13 C NMR (CD 3 OD, 100 MHz) data, see Table 2 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 469.3277 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 28 H 46 O 4 Na, 469.3294).

sec.title: 4.4. X-ray crystal structure analysis
sec.p: The crystallographic data of 1 , 2 , 4 , and 6 were deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (deposition numbers 2024115, 2024114, 2024062, and 2024238, respectively).

sec.title: 4.4.1. Crystal data for compound 1
sec.p: 2(C 29 H 46 O 4 )• H 2 O, M = 935.33, a = 7.1096(4) Å, b = 40.217(3) Å, c = 9.9359(5) Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 105.071(3) ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 2743.2(3) Å 3 , T = 100.(2) K, space group P 1211, Z = 2, μ (Cu Kα) = 0.584 mm 1 , 48608 reflections measured, 10648 independent reflections ( Rint = 0.1136). The final R 1 values were 0.0742 ( I > 2 σ ( I )). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.1802 ( I > 2 σ ( I )). The final R 1 values were 0.0988 (all data). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.2021 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.071. Flack parameter = 0.17(13).

sec.title: 4.4.2. Crystal data for compound 2
sec.p: C 28 H 44 O 4 • H 2 O, M = 462.65, a = 9.68210(10) Å, b = 43.6112(6) Å, c = 6.23620(10) Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 90 ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 2633.22(6) Å 3 , T = 100 (2) K, space group P 21212, Z = 4, μ (Cu Kα) = 0.618 mm 1 , 20993 reflections measured, 5175 independent reflections ( Rint = 0.0366). The final R 1 values were 0.0291 ( I > 2 σ ( I )). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.0700 ( I > 2 σ ( I )). The final R 1 values were 0.0311 (all data). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.0718 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.029. Flack parameter = 0.08(5).

sec.title: 4.4.3. Crystal data for compound 4
sec.p: 4(C 28 H 42 O 4 )• 2( CH 4 O)• H 2 O, M = 1825.55, monoclinic, a = 24.9410 (11) Å, b = 6.9131(4) Å, c = 32.3992(16) Å, α = 90.00 ◦ , β = 106.994 (3) ◦ , γ = 90.00 ◦ , V = 5342.3(5) Å 3 , T = 100(2) K, space group C121, Z = 2, μ (CuKα) = 1.5418 mm 1 , 56715 reflections measured, 10350 independent reflections ( Rint = 0.1255). The final R 1 values were 0.0923 ( I > 2 σ ( I )). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.2331 ( I > 2 σ ( I )). The final R 1 values were 0.1213 (all data). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 2565 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.056. Flack parameter = 0.04(18).

sec.title: 4.4.4. Crystal data for compound 6
sec.p: 2(C 28 H 46 O 4 )• ( CH 4 O)• H 2 O, M = 943.35, a = 13.3602(6) Å, b = 11.5802(5) Å, c = 17.5830(7) Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 102.3869(4) ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 2657.03(2) Å 3 , T = 293(2) K, space group P 21, Z = 2, μ (Cu Kα) = 0.619 mm 1 , 63690 reflections measured, 10566 independent reflections ( Rint = 0.0288). The final R 1 values were 0.0365 ( I > 2 σ ( I )). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.0987 ( I > 2 σ ( I )). The final R 1 values were 0.0367 (all data). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.0989 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.019. Flack parameter = -0.06(3).

sec.title: 4.5. Theoretical ECD calculation for compound 5
sec.p: The ECD calculation of 5 was implemented using Gaussian 09W. The electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra of each conformer were calculated at the B3LYP/6–311++ G(d,p)/B3LYP/6-31G (d) level, utilizing the TDDFT method with MeOH as the solvent and the IEFPCM solvation model performed in the Gaussian 09 program. The ECD spectra were simulated using a Gaussian function with a bandwidth σ of 0.3 eV. Based on the population contributions of the spectra, Boltzmann weighting was combined and a UV correction was applied.

sec.title: 4.6. Biological assay
sec.p: The human hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines, Hep3B, HepG2 and Huh-7 were purchased from Procell Life Technology Co. Ltd. (Wuhan, China ), and no evidence of mycoplasma contamination was detected by the PCR-based assay in any of these cell lines. Cells were cultured in Dulbecco’ s modified Eagle’ s medium (DMEM, HyClone, USA ) supplemented with 10% FBS (Gibco, USA ), 100 μ g/ml penicillin and 100 μ g/ml streptomycin (Biosharp, China ) in an incubator with at 37 ◦ C and a 5% CO 2 atmosphere. For cell treatment, compounds 1–13 and sorafenib (MCE, USA ), the positive control, were dissolved in DMSO and diluted to specific concentrations with a DMEM complete medium before use. Cell viability and IC 50 against hepatoma cell lines were tested via a CCK-8 (TOPSCIENCE, China ) assay according to the manufacturer’ s instructions. Flow cytometry analysis was performed in a BectonDickinson (BD) FACS Canto II flow cytometer (BD Biosciences, USA ) to determine cell cycle progression and apoptosis (Cell Cycle and Apoptosis Analysis Kit, Beyotime, China ). The relative distributions of cells in the G0/G1, S, and G2/M phases of the cell cycle were analyzed using Modfit 5.0 software and the rates of apoptotic cells were diagramed by FlowJo V10. For fluorescence microscopy detection of the apoptotic nuclear morphology, cells treated with various substrates were observed via fluorescence microscopy using a fluorescent microscope system (Olympus, Japan ) after DAPI staining (Solarbio Life Science, China ). GraphPad Prism 6 was used to perform the statistical analyses. For most experiments, two-tailed unpaired t-tests were used to determine statistically significant differences between groups. All experiments were performed at least three times and data are presented as the means ± standard deviation (s.d.) unless otherwise specified.
Associated content
The 1D and 2D NMR, MS, IR, UV, and X-ray crystallographic data of 1 , 2 , 4 , and 6 are included in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
Notes
The authors declare no competing financial interests.
